message.content: We refer to CDC guidelines for help. The boy received the first dose of Tdap at 8 years old and is due for a Td booster at 11 years old. He will then need a Tdap booster at 18 years old. Therefore, the pediatrician should choose option (D), a single dose of Td vaccine at now, and a single dose of Td vaccine at 18 years of age.

We refer to the CDC website for guidance on immunization schedules. According to the CDC, a catch-up Tdap vaccine can be given to children 7-10 years old who are not fully immunized against pertussis, followed by a single dose of Tdap at age 11-12. Since this patient received a catch-up Tdap at 8 years old, he should receive a single dose of Td vaccine now and then a single dose of Tdap at age 18.

We refer to CDC recommendations for immunization schedules. Since the patient already received a catch-up Tdap at age 8, the pediatrician should now administer a single dose of Td vaccine, which contains tetanus and diphtheria toxoids, but not pertussis vaccine. A booster dose of Tdap is recommended at age 11-12, which the patient has already received at age 8. After that, an additional booster dose of Tdap is recommended at age 16-18.

We refer to CDC guidelines for immunization for help. Since the boy has already received a dose of Tdap vaccine at the age of 8 years, he should receive a single dose of Td vaccine now and another dose of Td vaccine at 18 years of age. Tdap is recommended for adolescents aged 11-12 years and adults (including pregnant women) who have not previously received Tdap. However, the boy already received a catch-up series at the age of 8, so Td vaccine is the appropriate choice.

We refer to CDC guidelines for help. According to the guidelines, the recommended immunization schedule for children aged 11 through 18 years who start late or are more than 1 month behind should receive a single dose of Tdap followed by a booster dose of either Td or Tdap 10 years later. Since the patient received a catch-up Tdap vaccine at the age of 8, the pediatrician should administer a single dose of Td vaccine now and a booster dose of either Td or Tdap at 18 years of age.

We refer to the CDC immunization schedule for help. According to the catch-up immunization schedule, at age 11, the child should receive a single dose of Td vaccine now and another dose of Td vaccine at age 18. Tdap vaccine is recommended for adults and adolescents between the ages of 11 and 64 years who have not previously received it.

We refer to CDC recommendations for vaccination schedules. According to the catch-up immunization schedule, the child should receive a single dose of Td vaccine now, followed by a single dose of Tdap vaccine at 11-12 years of age. The option of waiting until 18 years of age for the Tdap vaccine is not in line with the recommended schedule.

We refer to the CDC website for help. Since the patient received a catch-up Tdap vaccination at 8 years old, the next booster dose should be a Td vaccine at age 11-12. Therefore, option (D) is the correct choice.

We refer to CDC guidelines on immunization for help. The boy already received a catch-up Tdap vaccine at age 8, so he now needs one dose of Td vaccine for continued protection against tetanus and diphtheria. A single dose of Tdap is recommended at age 11-12, but since he already had one at age 8, he can receive a single dose of Td vaccine now and a single dose of Tdap vaccine at age 18 to ensure continued protection against pertussis.

We refer to the CDC website for help. According to the catch-up vaccination schedule, the 11-year-old boy should receive a single dose of Td vaccine now and then another dose of Td vaccine at 18 years of age. The Tdap vaccine is recommended for adolescents aged 11-12 years, but since the patient already received a catch-up Tdap vaccine at 8 years of age, a single dose of Td vaccine is sufficient for now.
